EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.  INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES

This Risk Management Plan is part of the continuing commitment of SABIC Innovative Plastics US LLC (SABIC) to minimize the potential impact from our Ottawa, IL facility on our workers, our community neighbors, and the environment. It is the stated policy of SABIC to safely manage our site operations. In addition, we have prepared contingency plans to be used in the unlikely event that a major accident should occur. 
The efforts at our facility have been recognized by the US Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), which oversees our programs, as among the best in the nation for worker safety. 
SABIC believes it is important for all interested parties to have access to information that can help them better understand its business and the facility. 
 
2. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

SABIC is committed to operating safe and environmentally sound chemical and plastics production facilities everywhere we do business. Protection of the neighbors and workers is the highest priority. This ongoing commitment to worker and public safety is demonstrated through resources invested for safe design, operation, and maintenance of SABICs facilities.

In order to provide top-quality products for the customers, the Ottawa facility uses in its manufacturing process two raw materials that are classified as toxic or flammable. SABIC is committed to complying with governing laws, regulations, and engineering standards as well as conducting systematic assessments to manage and maintain a safe operation. SABIC's operating practices and procedures ensure that numerous controls are implemented to prevent an accidental release of a chemical. However, if a major release does occur, SABIC's trained on-site emergency response organization will be activated. This organization includes Emergency Response personnel trained in fighting fires, confined space rescue/rope rescue and hazardous material spill

response. The site has a nurse and employees trained at the first responder level of care

The outstanding safety programs at the Ottawa facility have earned the site OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) STAR status, presented by OSHA for exemplary safety management. This is OSHA's highest recognition for safety performance. 

In addition, the following specific prevention programs are in place:

Employee Participation
The employees and management work together to manage process safety and accident prevention efforts. Employees participate in process hazard reviews and in the development of operating procedures. They assist in updating and verifying technical documents and chemical information. Employees have access to all information created as part of this facility's accident prevention program. Employees are involved in developing and carrying out training, incident investigations, management of change, process hazard analyses and pre-startup safety reviews.

Process Safety Information
Technical information on process equipment, technology, and chemicals are maintained and used to ensure safe operation of the covered processes. These documents address chemical properties and their associated hazards, limits for critical process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design and configuration details. Specific departments are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDS). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and other known hazards associated with inadvertently mixing of chemicals. For specific covered process areas, there are documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperatures, pressures). Operators ensure that the process is maintained within these limits using

reliable process controls and monitoring instruments, emergency relief systems, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., emergency shutdown systems). Technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment are maintained digitally within the Ottawa plant's intranet. Hard copy back up of key critical information is maintained by Operations, EHSS, and Engineering. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Off-Site Consequence Analysis
The Ottawa Plant has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards and risks associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each new and altered process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. Methodologies used to perform these evaluations include the hazard and operability study (HAZOP) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA). These analyses are conducted using cross-functional teams with operations and engineering expertise. Team members identify and evaluate hazard scenarios, ranking each scenario's risk level with respect to event likelihood and severity. The team also evaluates prevention and mitigation measures and makes appropriate recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures if they are judged necessary. The site management team reviews the PHA team's findings and recommendations. The management team establishes priorities for implementation of PHA recommendations based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the team. This

ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios with the highest risk receive more immediate attention. All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained. The Ottawa Plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis studies using experience gained to improve process safety. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years for covered processes and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. Findings and recommendations from these updates are documented and retained. Recommendations made by the team updating or revalidating the PHA are again reviewed and resolved by management review with final resolution being documented and retained.

Operating Procedures
The Ottawa plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) startup following maintenance activities or following an emergency shutdown. Operating procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and a training resource in training new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and verified as current and accurate. Operating procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. When creating or reviewing operating procedures, a team of personnel review and comment on the drafts accuracy and completeness. Procedures are available to operators and other personnel in work areas where process operations are performed.

Training
Training is an essential part of the skills development program used for qualifying employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive initial training in plant rules and safety policies, process overviews, chemical and process hazar

ds, safe work practices, and basic emergency response procedures. Following classroom orientation, the new employee begins coworker training with an experienced operator and a review of operating procedures applicable to their job. At the conclusion of this co-worker-training period, the new employee is evaluated to ensure they possesses the skills and knowledge necessary to safely do their job. To supplement and reinforce job knowledge and skills, all employees undergo refresher training at regular intervals. Refresher training frequency ranges from each year to once every three years. Training is documented and understanding is verified using oral and written tests, performance observation and other means that objectively demonstrate understanding.

Contractor Safety Program
The Ottawa Plant employs contractors to perform special construction projects or supplement the maintenance workforce when needed. All contractors receive orientation training depending on the scope, nature, and location of their work. Contractors selection considers the existence and effectiveness of their safety programs and performance. Contractors undergo orientations where they are made aware of basic plant rules and safety policies, workplace hazards in the area they will work, safe work practices applicable to the jobs, and basic emergency response procedures. During this initial orientation, contract employees are instructed to report any hazards their work may create or that they discover during the course of their work. Contractors are periodically evaluated to ensure they are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Pre-Start-up Safety Reviews
The Ottawa Plant personnel perform pre-startup safety reviews for facility modifications beyond replacements of equipment in kind on covered processes. This includes significant changes in process equipment or procedures or upon completing the construction of new process facilities. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, proc

edures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service. This review provides additional verification that construction is in accordance with design specifications and that systems are operationally ready. Applicable checklists are used to verify various aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of equipment fabrication and installation and serves to assure that other accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
The Ottawa Plant assures the mechanical integrity of critical operations equipment such as pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, and safety systems through its mechanical integrity program. The basic aspects of the program include: (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Maintenance personnel receive training in (1) overviews of the process and its hazards, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) safe work practices to help ensure that they perform their jobs in a safe manner. Equipment deficiencies, once identified, are corrected prior to further operation of the equipment, or a management team will determine and prescribe how the equipment may continue safely in operation. As part of the mechanical integrity program, quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper material and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices
The Ottawa Plant employs widely accepted safety work practices and incorporates ten (10) Life Saving Rules into these Life Critical Proc

edures. These safe work practices used include (1) Safe systems of work which requires tasks without a procedure to have permits to perform tasks, (2) Confined Space Entry, (3) Working at Height, (4) Lifting Operations, (5) Energy Isolations  Lock out, Tag out, Try out, (6) Created Openings, (7) Disabling Safety Systems, (8) Vehicle Safety, (9) Line Breaks and (10) Management of Change These procedures are used by all personnel involved in both user and non-user maintenance activities.

Management of Change
The site's management of change program is intended to review and evaluate changes to process chemistry, operating conditions or limits, equipment, and procedures before changes are made so as to prevent unexpected adverse impacts. The management of change program uses a qualitative risk assessment to determine the significance of the change. This risk level assessment determines the levels of authorization required to approve the action. Design review checklists are used to evaluate different types of changes to prevent new hazards being created or equipment changes which are not suited to the service as it exists in the process. Another feature of the management of change program is that it verifies and documents that procedures, records, and equipment information are updated and that personnel affected by the change are informed of and trained in the change.

Incident Investigation
All incidents that result in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a release of a hazardous material, a fire or explosion in a covered process area, major property damage, offsite consequences, adverse environmental impact, or serious personal injury be reported and promptly investigated. By investigating accidents and near misses, important lessons are learned. Corrective actions can then be implemented to prevent similar events in the future. Incident investigations are documented, and recommendations tracked to their completion. Incident investigation reports are retained for a

t least 5 years to facilitate their use during PHA updates and revalidation.

Compliance Audits
To assure that the goals of the accident prevention programs are met, program performance is periodically evaluated in the form of compliance audits. An audit team reviews records and documents to determine the degree of program compliance. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. Audit team findings are documented and presented to plant management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to audit findings are tracked until they are complete. The two most recent audit reports are retained.

3. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The SABIC plant is located on a 215-acre tract along the Illinois River about three miles east of Ottawa, IL. It was built in 1967 and currently employs about 210 people. The plant manufactures engineered thermoplastic resins and pellets. The site products are used in the automotive, medical, electronics, computer, and appliance industries, to name a few. 

The Ottawa, IL plant uses two chemicals that are regulated under the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule: acrylonitrile, a regulated toxic substance, and 1,3-butadiene, a regulated flammable substance. Acrylonitrile and 1,3-butadiene are raw materials used to manufacture products. The facilitys covered processes are regulated under Level 3 RMP requirements. The acrylonitrile and 1,3-Butadiene processes are subject to Level 3 RMP requirements as they are categorized under the North American Industry Classification Systems (NAICS) listed in Section 68.10i of the RMP regulation (NAICS 325211). The 1,3-Butadiene processes containing more than 10,000 lbs are also subject to OSHA Process Safety Management regulation, 29 CFR 1910.119.
 
4. Prevention Program

SABIC has implemented a comprehensive PSM program to prevent accidental releases of highly hazardous chemicals. PSM is an integral part of working safely at SABIC facilities. PSM ensures that proper safet

accident prevention, which demonstrates its commitment to public and worker safety. Even minor incidents are investigated to identify what went wrong and to learn how to prevent future occurrences.
EPA requires that all incidents involving regulated chemicals that resulted in any off-site impact or significant on-site impact be reported in this document. Since the previous RMP submittal, there has been one accident that resulted in a personnel injury due to a tank fire, involving 1,3-Butadiene, in the Latex Operating Unit. This incident occurred on September 5th, 2023. The incident was reported to the Chemical Safety Board (CSB) as a result of the CSBs Accidental Release Reporting Rule as required by 42 U.S.C. 7412(r)(6)(C)(iii).

6. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Ottawa, IL site maintains a written emergency response program designed to protect workers, the public, and the environment in the event of a major accidental release. All of our employees are trained in the proper response to an incident. We also invest in the equipment needed to respond to emergencies, both on-site and off-site. The trained Emergency Response Team (ERT), medical (site nurse and First Responders), work closely with area hospitals, industries, and other response organizations in the Marseilles-Ottawa, IL area.
The ERT has received extensive training from the Illinois Fire Academy at the University of Illinois and Rock Island Arsenal Fire Department over the last 5 years. Training is conducted at the site on the Ottawa Site Emergency Response Plan, firefighting methods and operations, hazardous material response, and confined space/rope rescue.
Emergency medical response is a part of the Ottawa Site ERT system. First Responder personnel have been trained by the Ottawa Site Nurse under the direction and requirements of the Illinois Department of Public Health through OSF St. Elizabeth medical system and Marseilles area ambulance service to respond to potential medical emergency conditions

at the Emergency Medical System - First Responder level. In order to ensure prompt medical attention for serious conditions, the Ottawa Site has coordinated with Life Flight medical helicopter support centers (St. Francis-Peoria and Loyola- Chicago).
The Ottawa Site ERT has a Mutual Aid Agreement with the Marseilles Area Fire Protection District. Since the beginning of this relationship, SABIC, the District, and the Ottawa Fire Department have conducted joint training to further develop emergency response skills.
Working closely with the LaSalle County Local Emergency Planning Commission. Ongoing training exercises are important to the company's emergency response organization and help better prepare our partners in the community for emergency response necessary in the unlikely event of a major industrial incident.
SABIC personnel are assisting the LaSalle County Local Emergency Planning Commission in the development of a county-wide emergency plan. As is consistent with the LaSalle County emergency plan, SABIC will work through the Marseilles Area Fire Department to communicate any appropriate actions to be taken by the public in the event of a chemical emergency. 


7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

SABIC is committed to continuously improving the overall safety and environmental performance record at the Ottawa, IL facility. Some of the specific planned changes aimed at improving safety are: 
- Continuing development of best management practices under OSHA's VPP program;
- Improved safety procedures and practices for control of hazardous emergency during maintenance activities;  
- Improvements in the plant's Management Of Change  program as well as the Process Hazard Analysis/Levels of Protection Analysis.
- Expanded use of our SAFER Risk Management and mitigation practices.
- Utilizing the e-Audit system for the Operations Management Systems/Safety, Health, and Environmental Management systems.
- An ongoing employee exposure monitoring and reduction program

for 1,3-butadiene and acrylonitrile.
- Utilizing an extensive series of alarms and interlocks that maintain our extrusion processes within safe parameters, and shut the process down before an excursion can take place.
